articles.content:
Shopping for ACA health plans this open enrollment? Here's what to know 
         By Michelle Andrews 
        
           Friday, October 31, 2025 • 5:00 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         This year's Obamacare open enrollment period, which starts Saturday in most states, is full of uncertainty and confusion for the more than  24 million people  who buy health insurance through the federal and state Affordable Care Act marketplaces. The fate of the enhanced premium tax credits that make coverage more affordable for  92% of enrollees  remains up in the air, with the prospect of significantly  higher premiums looming . But there are steps marketplace shoppers can take to ensure they make the right choices for the upcoming plan year. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       1. Understand how we got here In 2021, as part of a COVID-era relief package, the ACA premium tax credits were enhanced to lower costs for previously eligible people and expand eligibility to people with incomes over 400% of the federal poverty level (which amounts to  about $63,000  for one person in 2025). But those enhancements, which were extended in 2022,  will expire  at the end of 2025 unless Congress acts. The debate over whether to extend them again has been at the center of a political battle of wills between Republicans and Democrats in Congress, a fight at the heart of the now month-old  government shutdown. The financial implications for many marketplace enrollees are huge. Average out-of-pocket premium payments for subsidized enrollees are projected to more than double if the enhanced tax credits expire, according to KFF, a health information nonprofit that includes KFF Health News. "The longer this goes on, the more damage is done," said  Cynthia Cox , a vice president and the director of the Program on the ACA at KFF. "If someone logs on Nov. 1 and sees their premium doubling, they might just walk away." That would be a mistake, marketplace experts agree. What is clear, though, is that buyers need to beware and be informed. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       2. Follow the news It can be frustrating to track day-to-day Capitol Hill machinations. But that may be your best source for up-to-date information. Congress could make a deal to extend the enhanced subsidies anytime during the next few days, weeks or months -- or not. Either way, it could affect your enrollment decision. So, pay attention. Don't count on the marketplace or your insurer to notify you about what you should expect to pay. "Many state marketplaces have hit delay" on sending consumers notices of net premiums, which take premium tax credits into account, said  Sabrina Corlette , a co-director of Georgetown University's Center on Health Insurance Reforms. The federal government doesn't send enrollees notices about plan premiums for the coming year for the  28 federally facilitated  marketplaces. For 2026, it has said that health plans can also  opt not  to. 3. Update your account information and don't auto-enroll Log in to your marketplace account and update your income, household size, and any other details that have changed. This year, it's particularly important to provide an accurate estimate of your anticipated income for 2026. A provision in HR 1, sometimes called the  One Big Beautiful Bill Act ,  eliminated the caps  on what many people were required to repay if they underestimated their projected income and received more premium assistance than they should have. Next year, people will have to repay the entire excess amount. In the past few years, it's been possible to put your ACA insurance on auto-pilot with  automatic reenrollment  in your current or a similar plan. Given the uncertainty around premiums, this is not a good year to do that, enrollment specialists say. This is especially true for people who, without a deal in Congress, will no longer qualify for subsidies next year, specifically those whose incomes are over 400% of the federal poverty level. 4. Shop based on sticker prices When people see their projected premiums, assuming Congress hasn't reached a deal to extend the enhanced credits, many will be shocked. Health insurance premiums on the marketplaces are expected to increase, on average, 26% next year,  according to KFF . That's the largest rate increase since 2018. Until now, people have largely been shielded from those increases by the enhanced premium tax subsidies that nearly all enrollees receive. Here's how it works: Most people with ACA marketplace plans are responsible for paying a portion of their premium based on a sliding income scale, and the government pays the rest. According to an analysis by KFF, if the enhanced credits are not renewed, a family of four with $75,000 in income, for example,  will be responsible  for paying $5,865 in annual premiums for a benchmark silver plan in 2026 — more than double the $2,498 it'll pay if they are renewed. When evaluating a plan, focus on the listed price. If it's not affordable without the enhanced tax credits, it's not a good buy. "People need to make a decision based on what is in front of them," Cox said. If you can't afford the sticker price without the enhanced credits, consider enrolling in a less generous plan with a lower premium but a higher deductible, Cox said. Bronze plans must provide comprehensive coverage, including covering preventive care at no cost, and may cover some doctor visits before the deductible. "In most cases, it makes more sense to have a bronze plan than to be uninsured," she said. The Trump administration has been promoting  catastrophic plans  as a more affordable option for people who face financial hardship, including those who don't qualify for subsidies because their incomes are either less than 100% or more than 400% of the federal poverty level. Similar to bronze plans, catastrophic plans cover a set of essential health benefits, provide free preventive care, and must cover at least three doctor visits before people reach their deductible. But catastrophic plan deductibles are the highest of any type of marketplace plan: $10,600 for individuals and $21,200 for families in 2026. "They are expensive relative to what they cover," said  Jennifer Sullivan , director of health coverage access at the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, noting premiums can cost several hundred dollars. 5. Come back, check, and recheck If you're dismayed at premium prices on your first pass, "don't slam the computer shut and decide that there are no options for you," Sullivan said. "Congress might still act and things might change radically." Lawmakers could restore the enhanced premium tax credits right up to the end of the year, or later. In a majority of states, including the 28 that use the federal government's centralized marketplace, open enrollment lasts until Jan. 15. There are also other key dates to remember. In most states, people  must enroll  by Dec. 15 for coverage starting Jan. 1, and by Jan. 15 for coverage starting Feb. 1, though some states have later deadlines. 6. Wait to pay your premium Premium payments are generally due before the plan takes effect, although marketplaces and insurers have flexibility to extend deadlines, Corlette said. They might allow people extra time to make a first payment, for example. "We've seen that in the past. State officials and insurance companies have gotten creative to try and keep people in coverage," she said. But if there is a last-minute deal and someone has already paid their premium for January coverage and received a lower tax credit than the deal provides, they should still be able to receive the higher credit. "There are ways to make people whole," Corlette said, although how that might happen this enrollment period is unclear. KFF Health News  is a national newsroom that produces in-depth journalism about health issues and is one of the core operating programs at  KFF .

articles.title: Russia Launches Massive Drone and Missile Attacks on Ukraine’s Energy Grid as Winter Approaches
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In a sustained Russian campaign, over 650 drones and 50 missiles were launched on Ukraine’s energy infrastructure on October 30, 2025, causing widespread power outages, injuries, and deaths, including children. The attacks targeted key cities such as Sloviansk, Zaporizhzhia, Vinnytsia, and Lviv, disrupting essential services like heating, water, and sewage. Ukrainian officials, including President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and Prime Minister Yulia Svyrydenko, labeled the actions as 'systematic energy terror,' aimed at eroding morale and destabilizing civilian life as winter approaches. The Polish military responded by scrambling aircraft and closing regional airports due to the threat to its territory, demonstrating the cross-border security impact. Ukraine is calling for stronger air defenses, sanctions, and international pressure to counter the attacks, which are part of a broader strategy to weaken Ukraine’s resilience during critical winter conditions.

The attacks resulted in at least six deaths, including a 7-year-old girl, and 18 injuries, with multiple children among the injured.

The Polish military responded by scrambling allied aircraft and closing regional airports in Radom and Lublin as a precaution.
Ukraine is calling for more air defense systems, tougher sanctions, and sustained international pressure on Russia to halt the attacks.
This campaign is part of a broader strategy to undermine Ukrainian resilience and war effort, especially as winter temperatures rise.

articles.title: The Trump administration move to study aluminum in vaccines worries scientists
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration has initiated a study on the safety of aluminum in vaccines, a common adjuvant used in vaccines for diseases like diphtheria, tetanus, and influenza. While public health experts, including former FDA officials and vaccine scientists, affirm that aluminum is safe and effective, and that removing it would severely compromise vaccine efficacy and public health, the move has raised alarms. Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has long questioned aluminum’s safety, and a CDC advisory committee is reviewing potential risks, such as asthma. A major Danish study found no link between aluminum and serious illnesses in children. Critics like Christopher Exley argue aluminum is harmful and welcome its removal, though this view lacks scientific consensus. Experts warn that eliminating aluminum could lead to disease resurgence, erode public trust, and require years of development for safe alternatives. The article underscores the tension between public concern and scientific evidence, calling for cautious, evidence-based policy decisions.

Public health experts, including Dr. Jesse Goodman and Dr. Stanley Plotkin, state that aluminum is safe and effective and that removing it would render vaccines ineffective and could undermine public health and trust in immunization.

Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. has long criticized aluminum in vaccines, and a special working group under the CDC’s Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices is reviewing aluminum adjuvants, particularly whether they increase the risk of asthma.

Some critics, such as Christopher Exley, believe aluminum is inherently harmful and welcome efforts to remove it, though such claims lack scientific consensus.
Removing aluminum would require years of research to develop safe alternatives and could lead to a resurgence of preventable diseases, as seen with measles.
Federal officials have not announced plans to remove aluminum from vaccines, but acknowledge ongoing review of the scientific evidence.

articles.content:
The Trump administration move to study aluminum in vaccines worries scientists 
         By Rob Stein 
        
           Friday, October 31, 2025 • 7:00 AM EDT 
        
        
      

         The Trump administration is studying the safety of an ingredient commonly used in vaccines, an additive that contains aluminum.  Coming after other recent  changes to vaccine policy ,  many public health experts worry that the administration may now try to remove the ingredient.  "We want no aluminum in the vaccine," President Trump said recently at a White House briefing.  For almost a century, some important vaccines, including shots that protect against diphtheria, tetanus, hepatitis and the flu, have included aluminum salts, compounds that contain small amounts of  aluminum . They are used as adjuvants to give the immune system an extra kick necessary to make the shots protective. "Aluminum is added to some vaccines because it's a very safe, but also effective, stimulant of the immune system," says Dr.  Jesse Goodman , a vaccine expert at Georgetown University who used to regulate vaccines at the Food and Drug Administration. "It basically stimulates your cells to make more antibodies and a stronger immune response overall." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       But Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a longtime vaccine critic, has questioned the safety of aluminum in vaccines for years. And a special working group is now studying the "safety of ingredients that are present in multiple different vaccines," including aluminum, for the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention's influential Advisory Committee on Immunization Practices. One question the working group is considering is "do either of the two different aluminum adjuvants increase the risk of asthma?" according to a  document  outlining the group's mandate. Most public health experts say there's no good evidence that aluminum is unsafe and ample evidence that it poses no real concern. In fact, a  large Danish study  recently debunked any danger. "We do not see any evidence that aluminum is a cause of serious illness in childhood," says  Anders Hviid , a professor of epidemiology at the Statens Serum Institut in Denmark who led the study involving more than 1.2 million Danish children. "There is no scientific reason to take aluminum out of childhood vaccines. There's no science that supports that it's dangerous." But some researchers welcome the move. "I really believe that aluminum in vaccines is inherently bad. Full stop," says  Christopher Exley , a longtime critic of aluminum in vaccines who recently retired from Keele University in the U.K. "And so any suggestion that we're going to remove it, I think, is absolutely marvelous, not only for making America healthy again but for making the world healthy again." 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       In addition to concerns over asthma, Exley thinks aluminum can  also increase the risk for other  health problems , including autism and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.  Hviid and others say trying to remove aluminum would cause significant problems for protecting people against serious diseases. Most importantly, the vaccines that contain aluminum would be rendered ineffective. "To simply remove aluminum — in effect destroying or limiting the effectiveness of vaccines — is incredibly stupid," says Dr.  Stanley Plotkin , a leading authority on vaccine science at the University of Pennsylvania. People are exposed to far more aluminum in the environment than from vaccines, Plotkin notes.  And if federal regulators deem aluminum unsafe as a vaccine ingredient, vaccine makers would have to develop and test alternatives, a process that could take years. Such a move could undermine public trust in existing vaccines.  "And what has happened with measles will happen with other diseases — that is, coming back to this country," Plotkin says. "So, do we want that? Well, apparently some people do."  Federal health officials have not stated that they would pull existing vaccines with aluminum salts from the market, or that they want any diseases to return.  HHS press secretary Emily G. Hilliard declined to respond to specific questions about the safety of aluminum adjuvants or the practicality of removing them, but said in an emailed statement that "ACIP is reviewing the body of science related to aluminum and other possible contaminants in childhood vaccine." And some scientists are open to at least studying the question of removing aluminum salts.  "It's human nature to try to make things even better, right?" says Dr.  Ofer Levy,  a pediatrician who runs the Precision Vaccines Program at Boston Children's Hospital. "So with all of the sophisticated science we have in the year 2025, probably there's room for improvement." But Levy stresses that any changes should only be made if unbiased, well-conducted studies support that. In the meantime, Levy and others say that no one should hesitate about getting a vaccine containing aluminum. "The question becomes: How do we give voice to legitimate concerns about vaccines without throwing the baby out with the bathwater?" Levy says.

articles.title: Trump says he wants to resume nuclear testing. Here's what that would mean
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: President Donald Trump has announced the intention to resume nuclear testing in the United States for the first time in over 30 years, citing Russia’s recent tests of nuclear-powered cruise missiles and an underwater drone as justification. The only site available for such testing is the Nevada National Security Site, 60 miles northwest of Las Vegas, where underground tests would involve drilling deep shafts and detonating nuclear devices. Experts, including Corey Hinderstein and Don Haynes, argue that such a move would be dangerous, expensive (estimated at $140 million per test), and unnecessary, as the U.S. currently relies on advanced simulations and historical data from over 1,000 past tests to maintain weapon reliability. While testing may serve as a political signal to counter Russian developments, it would likely escalate global tensions, undermine the post-Cold War test moratorium, and risk environmental and structural damage in nearby areas like Las Vegas. The decision raises serious concerns about a potential new arms race and the stability of nuclear deterrence.
keyTakeAways: The United States has not tested a nuclear weapon since 1992, and resuming testing would be a significant departure from decades of nuclear restraint.
The only site available for nuclear testing in the U.S. is the Nevada National Security Site, located approximately 60 miles northwest of Las Vegas.
Underground testing involves drilling deep shafts into mountain formations, placing a nuclear device in a sealed chamber, and detonating it to contain fallout.
Experts warn that resuming nuclear testing could be extremely dangerous, leading to radioactive leaks, seismic damage to structures in Las Vegas, and a dangerous escalation of the nuclear arms race.
Russia's recent tests of nuclear-powered cruise missiles and an underwater drone have prompted President Trump to suggest a reciprocal test, indicating a potential renewed arms race.
The U.S. currently relies on supercomputer simulations and historical data from over 1,000 past tests to ensure nuclear weapon reliability, reducing the need for physical testing.

The resumption of testing would signal a major shift in nuclear strategy and could undermine global nuclear stability, especially as it undermines the post-Cold War test moratorium.

articles.content:
Trump says he wants to resume nuclear testing. Here's what that would mean 
         By Geoff Brumfiel 
        
           Thursday, October 30, 2025 • 1:06 PM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  All Things Considered 
        
      

         President Trump said on Thursday that  the U.S. would begin testing nuclear weapons again  for the first time in decades. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       "We've halted many years ago, but with others doing testing I think it's appropriate to do so," the president told reporters aboard Air Force One. Experts say that the resumption of testing would be a major escalation and could upend the nuclear balance of power. "I think a decision to resume nuclear testing would be extremely dangerous and would do more to benefit our adversaries than the United States," said Corey Hinderstein, vice president for studies at the Carnegie Endowment for Nuclear Peace. Here's what a test would involve, and why the president might be calling for one now. There's currently only one place America could test a nuke — near Las Vegas, Nevada The Nevada National Security Site , approximately 60 miles northwest of Las Vegas, is currently the only place where America could test a nuclear weapon, said Robert Peters, a senior research fellow for strategic deterrence at the Heritage Foundation. 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       The Nevada site is around 1,300 square miles in size, larger than the state of Rhode Island. Starting in the 1950s, scientists conducted atmospheric nuclear tests at the site, but from 1962 to 1992, testing was done underground. Today, testing would likely be done in "a complex of deep underground mineshafts," Peters said. Scientists dig a deep shaft either directly below ground or into the side of a mountain. They then put a nuclear device in a chamber at the end of the shaft and seal it up. The detonation is contained by the rock, reducing the risk of atmospheric fallout. Although underground testing is far safer than atmospheric testing, it still carries risks, said Hinderstein. In the past, some radioactive fallout has leaked from test shafts. Additionally, the test could shake buildings as far away as Las Vegas, and Hinderstein said some of the newer buildings in Vegas could even be at risk of damage. "All of these big high-rises — including Stratosphere, including the Trump Hotel," she said. "They're not designed for massive, significant seismic activity." America's last test in Nevada was over 30 years ago At the end of the Cold War, the world's major nuclear powers declared a voluntary moratorium on nuclear testing. Russia, then the Soviet Union, tested its last nuclear weapon in 1990, the U.S. conducted its final test in 1992, and China conducted its last test in 1996. The voluntary test moratorium has been in place as part of an effort to maintain nuclear stability. The U.S currently uses scientific experiments and supercomputer simulations to make sure its bombs still work. Last year, NPR was one of a handful of organizations granted  rare access  to the top-secret underground tunnels where the tests take place. Scientists working in the tunnels said they were confident they could continue to ensure the safety of America's nuclear weapons without testing. Although a full-scale nuclear detonation would be "complementary" to current experiments, "our assessment is that there are no system questions that would be answered by a test, that would be worth the expense and the effort and the time," Don Haynes, a nuclear weapons scientist from Los Alamos National Laboratory told NPR as they walked through the tunnels. Indeed Hinderstein says, preparing for a nuclear test is no small matter. While a basic demonstration test could be done in approximately 18 months. Conducting a test that would produce scientifically useful data would likely take years. Trump's announcement is likely reacting to some recent tests by Russia On Sunday,  Russia announced  it had conducted a successful test of a new nuclear-powered cruise missile. Then on Wednesday President Vladimir Putin announced the successful test of another doomsday weapon —  a nuclear-powered underwater drone , which Russia says can be used to attack coastal cities. Trump never called out Russia by name, but he did suggest recent testing was behind the announcement. "I see them testing," he said aboard Air Force One, "and I say, 'Well if they're going to test I guess we have to test.'" 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       While testing nuclear-powered weapons is not the same as testing nuclear weapons themselves, Russia's tests are highly provocative. They come just months before the expiration of the last nuclear treaty between the U.S. and Russia, designed to put limits on their arsenals. The back-and-forth has all the hallmarks of the start of an arms race, noted Jon Wolfsthal, the director of global risk at the Federation for American Scientists. "We saw this play out throughout the Cold War through nuclear testing, nuclear deployments, nuclear investments," he said. Many experts warn that now is not the time to resume nuclear testing Hinderstein, who served as a deputy administrator of the National Nuclear Security Administration, the agency responsible for America's nuclear weapons, from 2021 to 2024, said that a decision to resume testing would not be in America's interests. By the end of the Cold War, the U.S. had conducted more than a thousand nuclear tests — far more than any other nation (China, by comparison, had conducted just 45). 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       Other nations "have more to gain by resuming nuclear testing than the United States does," she said. Testing would likely be expensive, adds Paul Dean, vice president for global nuclear policy at the Nuclear Threat Initiative. "The cost estimates I've seen have been at around, ballpark, $140 million per test," he said. "It's not necessary to conduct a nuclear explosive test right now," agreed Robert Peters of the Heritage Foundation. But he added, "But there could very well be compelling reasons to test in the coming months and years. That's how bad things are getting." 
         
         Transcript 
         JUANA SUMMERS, HOST:   It has been 33 years since the United States last tested a nuclear weapon. Now President Trump says he wants to do it again. Here he is on Air Force One earlier today. (SOUNDBITE OF ARCHIVED RECORDING) PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP: You know, we have more than anybody. But I see them testing. I say, well, if they're go to test, I guess we have to test. SUMMERS: What might the president mean by that? Let's bring in NPR science and security correspondent Geoff Brumfiel. Hi. GEOFF BRUMFIEL, BYLINE: Hi there. SUMMERS: So Geoff, the president said, if they're going to test, I guess we have to test. So I guess my question is, who's they? BRUMFIEL: Yeah. It wasn't entirely clear from what he said, but experts I spoke to today agree it's almost certainly Russia. On Sunday, Russia announced it had successfully tested a nuclear-powered cruise missile. Then yesterday, it said it had tested a nuclear-powered torpedo. Now, nuclear-powered things obviously aren't the same as nuclear bombs, but both the missile and torpedo are designed to carry nuclear warheads. And these tests are very provocative because these devices could get around Trump's proposed Golden Dome missile defense system. SUMMERS: OK. So if the U.S. were to test a nuclear weapon, let's say, what would be involved? BRUMFIEL: Well, first of all, there's only one place they can do it, and that's in the desert outside of Las Vegas, Nevada. It's a place called the Nevada National Security Site. It's absolutely massive. I was out there last year. It's bigger than the state of Rhode Island. SUMMERS: Huh. BRUMFIEL: Basically, they dig a hole, bury the weapon thousands of feet underground, and then they detonate it. Corey Hinderstein is at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, and until last year, she was high up in the agency that manages America's nuclear weapons. She told me this. COREY HINDERSTEIN: The president is talking about sending a signal. And if the goal is to shake the ground, then we could do it on the timeline that he's required. BRUMFIEL: But the test site is not ready to do a really scientific test. They don't have the experiment design. They don't have the instrumentation. That kind of test would take years to develop because the U.S. hasn't tested since 1992. SUMMERS: Well, why has it been so long since the U.S. tested a nuclear weapon? BRUMFIEL: At the end of the Cold War, the world's great nuclear powers voluntarily stopped testing kind of as a gesture of goodwill. That voluntary moratorium has held in part because the U.S. has spent billions of dollars on supercomputers to simulate nuclear weapons. They like to call it a bang in a box. And actually, many experts told me the moratorium works to the U.S.' advantage. They have data from over a thousand nuclear tests already on the books. China, by contrast, for example, has just 45. Hinderstein says America's adversaries would gain a lot more from additional testing than the U.S. would. HINDERSTEIN: While we could potentially gain incrementally - but even that is questionable - they could stand to gain a lot and not suffer the political hit by being the first to resume testing. BRUMFIEL: I should add, there are possible environmental consequences too. Radioactive material can leak from underground sometimes. And there's some concern that shaking from the test could actually damage buildings all the way in Vegas. SUMMERS: So Geoff, the Russians have tested these new weapons, and America may test a nuclear bomb for the first time in decades. So I do have to ask, is this a new arms race? BRUMFIEL: You know, the experts I spoke to were divided on that. During the Cold War, we had so many nukes, and so did the Russia. It was sort of insane. Now, things aren't as bad as they used to be, but everyone agrees these are the dynamics that drive an arms race. You know, one side does one thing, and then the other side says, I've got to look strong, so I'm going to respond with something else. So there's a lot of concern over what's happening. SUMMERS: NPR's Geoff Brumfiel, thank you. BRUMFIEL: Thank you.

articles.title: Mexico’s Cempasuchil Farmers Face Climate Crisis Amid Traditional Day of the Dead Tradition
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Farmers in Mexico’s Xochimilco region are struggling to sustain their traditional cempasuchil (Mexican marigold) cultivation in the face of worsening climate conditions, including heavy rains and flooding, which have destroyed up to half of their crops. The flower is central to Mexico’s Day of the Dead celebrations, symbolizing a spiritual connection between the living and the dead, and serves as a vital economic activity for rural farmers. However, the shift toward using uniform, commercially viable hybrid seeds from the U.S. has reduced genetic diversity and made the plants more susceptible to climate extremes. In response, scientists at the Toxinachcal seed bank are preserving native cempasuchil variants to ensure long-term resilience. Farmers like Lucia Ortiz and Carlos Jiménez report severe financial losses and are considering alternatives or abandoning farming due to shrinking profits and crop failures, raising concerns about the survival of this deeply rooted cultural and agricultural tradition in the face of climate change.
keyTakeAways: Cempasuchil flower farming is central to Mexico’s Day of the Dead traditions, symbolizing a bridge between the living and the dead.
Farmers in Mexico City’s Xochimilco region face increasing crop losses due to climate change, including heavy rains, droughts, and flooding.
The use of hybrid marigold seeds from the U.S. has reduced genetic diversity, making native cempasuchil plants more vulnerable to climate extremes.
A government-backed seed bank known as Toxinachcal is preserving native cempasuchil variants to combat climate-related crop failures.
Farmers like Lucia Ortiz and Carlos Jiménez are experiencing financial hardship, with some losing up to 50% of their crops and facing shrinking profit margins.
Farmers are considering alternatives such as greenhouses or new crops due to the increasing difficulty of sustaining traditional farming practices.
The tradition of growing cempasuchil is deeply tied to cultural identity, and its potential loss represents a broader threat to heritage and intergenerational knowledge.

articles.title: Deputy Found Guilty of Second-Degree Murder in Sonya Massey Case
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In Springfield, Illinois, Deputy Sean Grayson was found guilty of second-degree murder after shooting and killing Sonya Massey in her home on July 6, 2024. The incident occurred during a police visit prompted by a 911 call about a suspected prowler, and Grayson claimed he believed Massey intended to harm him when she grabbed a boiling pot of water and said, 'I rebuke you in the name of Jesus.' Prosecutors argued that Grayson should have sent a replacement officer and that his actions violated police training, leading to a fatal outcome. The jury, given the option under Illinois law of second-degree murder for unreasonable but honest beliefs in danger, ultimately convicted Grayson of a lesser charge, drawing criticism from Massey’s family and supporters who saw it as unjust. The case highlights tensions around police use of force, racial disparities, and community trust in law enforcement, especially in domestic settings involving Black women.
keyTakeAways: The killing of Sonya Massey, a Black woman, by Sheriff’s Deputy Sean Grayson in her own kitchen was initially pursued as a first-degree murder case, but the jury found him guilty of second-degree murder.
The verdict sparked outrage from Massey’s family and supporters, who viewed it as unjust due to the deliberate shooting in the face by a white officer in a domestic setting.
Deputy Grayson claimed he believed Massey intended to harm him when she grabbed a boiling pot of water and said, 'I rebuke you in the name of Jesus,' which he interpreted as a threat.
Under Illinois law, second-degree murder allows for the defense of an unreasonable but honest belief in danger, which may justify a lesser charge.
The jury was given the option to consider second-degree murder due to the presence of plausible, though disputed, beliefs of self-defense, a common practice in Illinois courts.
Prosecutors argued that Grayson failed to follow police protocol by not sending a replacement officer, stating that if another officer had been sent, Massey would still be alive.
Defense attorney Daniel Fultz emphasized that the belief in threat does not equate to actual threat, and that the jury should not assume intent to kill.
State’s Attorney John Milhiser stated he will seek the maximum possible sentence when Grayson is sentenced, reflecting the gravity of the incident.
The case highlights ongoing tensions around police use of force, racial disparities, and trust in law enforcement, especially in cases involving Black women and domestic settings.

articles.title: Scientists Thought This Fossil Was a Teen T. rex. Turns Out It's a New Tyrannosaur
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The 'Dueling Dinosaurs' fossil, discovered in eastern Montana in 2006, was initially thought to contain a juvenile Tyrannosaurus rex. However, a comprehensive analysis led by paleontologists Lindsay Zanno and James Napoli, published in the journal Nature, reveals that the carnivorous dinosaur is actually a fully grown individual of the species Nanotyrannus lancensis — a species long dismissed by the scientific community. Additional analysis uncovered a second tyrannosaur species, Nanotyrannus lethaeus. This discovery challenges the long-held belief that T. rex was the sole top predator in late Cretaceous ecosystems, suggesting instead that multiple tyrannosaur species coexisted, indicating a more diverse and flourishing ecosystem before the asteroid extinction event. The study not only shifts scientific understanding but also highlights the importance of reevaluating prior assumptions and the potential for many species to have been overlooked in fossil records.
keyTakeAways: The 'Dueling Dinosaurs' fossil, discovered in 2006 in eastern Montana, was initially thought to contain a juvenile Tyrannosaurus rex, but new research has revealed it includes a fully grown individual of a distinct tyrannosaur species, Nanotyrannus lancensis.

Scientists Lindsay Zanno and James Napoli, through detailed analysis including 3D modeling and growth ring examination, concluded that the carnivorous dinosaur in the fossil was not a juvenile T. rex, but a mature, small-bodied predator with powerful arms and more teeth than T. rex.

This discovery overturns the long-standing scientific consensus that T. rex was the sole top predator in its ecosystem, suggesting instead that multiple tyrannosaur species coexisted during the late Cretaceous.

The study identifies two new tyrannosaur species: Nanotyrannus lancensis (a species first proposed in the 1940s but dismissed) and a newly named Nanotyrannus lethaeus, derived from the mythological River Lethe, symbolizing the idea of being 'reincarnated' or previously unrecognized.
The findings indicate that late Cretaceous ecosystems were more diverse and flourishing than previously believed, refuting the notion that dinosaurs were declining before the asteroid impact.
Paleontologists now face a reevaluation of what a juvenile T. rex looked like, as many previously assumed 'teenage' T. rex specimens may actually have been individuals of the Nanotyrannus species.
The research highlights the importance of scientific self-correction, emphasizing that science progresses by questioning and revising prior beliefs.

articles.content:
Scientists thought this fossil was a teen T. rex. Turns out it's a new tyrannosaur 
         By Ari Daniel 
        
           Thursday, October 30, 2025 • 1:04 PM EDT 
        
        
           Heard on  All Things Considered 
        
      

         It's known as the "Dueling Dinosaurs" fossil: A triceratops and a tyrannosaur, skeletons entangled, locked in apparent combat right up until the moment of their mutual demise. Even in the Hell Creek Formation in eastern Montana, a spot known for great finds, this specimen was, in a word, "fantabulous," says  Clayton Phipps , a self-described rancher, cowboy and dinosaur hunter. That discovery in 2006 now appears to have overturned decades of dinosaur dogma about  Tyrannosaurus rex , the fearsome giant long thought to be the sole top predator stalking the late Cretaceous. In a paper in the journal  Nature , paleontologists  Lindsay Zanno  and  James Napoli  conclude that some of the bones from that specimen belong not to a teenage  T. rex , but to a fully grown individual of a different tyrannosaur species —  Nanotyrannus lancensis . 
       
      Related Story:  NPR 
       The majority of paleontologists, after some debate, had dismissed the idea that any other tyrannosaurs existed besides  T. rex . And yet, the sands of Montana seem to have disgorged a second one. In a broader analysis of other fossils, the two researchers also uncovered what they say is a third tyrannosaur species, formerly presumed to be a juvenile  T. rex . "We knew the specimen was exceptional," says Zanno. "We did not realize it would turn decades of research about  T. rex  on its head." "Just insanely good"   The Montana dig began on a breezy summer day when Phipps' friend, Mark Eatman, found an exposed pelvis and femur at the bottom of a canyon. Phipps thought maybe there was half a dinosaur hidden below. But after two weeks of digging, Phipps and his older cousin revealed that those bones belonged to a stunning triceratops. "It was crazier than any site I've ever done before or since because every bone is in place," he says. "The skeleton was just all together — just insanely good." Then, while excavating the light yellow sand from around the specimen, Phipps spotted something the color of chocolate. It was a claw. But triceratops didn't have claws. "I'm like, 'What?' I start brushing and all of a sudden this arm starts to appear and part of the leg," he recalls. "Oh man, my hat went in the air about 200 feet. I was like, 'No way — there's another dinosaur in here.'" This was a bipedal,  carnivorous  dinosaur, entwined with the triceratops. "Just laying like they died," says Phipps. The scientific consensus pegged this second dinosaur as a teenage  Tyrannosaurus rex  — a conclusion that would soon be overturned. Teenage angst A few years ago, the nonprofit  Friends of the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences  acquired the fossils and rock they were encased in (some 30,000 pounds) from Phipps and donated them to the museum. "They were a Christmas present waiting to be unwrapped," he says. Zanno, who is head of paleontology at the museum, was thrilled. "It's one of the most incredible specimens from the late Cretaceous in North America I've ever seen," she says. She and the museum built  an entire wing around the dueling dinosaurs  to house a live-action research experience. "It's the only place in the world where you get to enter the working paleo-lab without a barrier and talk to the scientific team that's working on the fossils," says Zanno. When that work began, Zanno also figured the carnivorous dinosaur was the world's most complete juvenile  T. rex  ever found. "But as soon as we started actually studying this specimen, we realized there were a lot of red flags," she says. For context, paleontologists had previously debated whether small-bodied tyrannosaurs were teenage  T. rexes  or a different species altogether. The existence of a two-legged tyrannosaur species that lived alongside  T. rex  was proposed back in the 1940s, but had long since fallen out of favor. The consensus converged on juvenile  T. rex , "meaning it would have been the only major predator in end-Cretaceous ecosystems right before the asteroid impact," says Zanno. Most researchers believed that  T. rex  — which could be  12 feet high , 40 feet long and weigh around 15,000 pounds — had outcompeted all other meat-eating dinosaurs. The completeness of the new skeleton provided Zanno with the ideal specimen to test these long-standing conclusions. "This is such a controversial topic," she says. "And we don't want to write another paper that just stirs the pot. We want to write the paper that ends the debate." The dueling dinosaurs settle a duel One of the first of those red flags in the new specimen was the arm bones. They looked completely different than  T. rex 's puny appendages. "We never had a complete arm of this animal," says Zanno. "These are powerful arms with large claws, large hands. They were using them for prey capture." Contrast that with  T. rex , "an animal that's a mouth on legs." There were additional clues. The animal had fewer tail vertebrae and more teeth than  T. rex . Zanno and Napoli considered other lines of evidence. They created 3D models of numerous purported  T. rex es against which they compared their specimen. They looked at the growth stages of the cranial nerves and sinuses of close living relatives of dinosaurs, features that were visible in the fossilized skeleton. "But maybe the most important and damning thing that we did was we were able to figure out that our animal is not a juvenile at all," she says. This conclusion was based on slicing through the fossil's limb bones to examine the growth rings. That work demonstrated that this animal was mature and done growing when it died around the age of 20. "That means it's half the size and a tenth of the mass of a full grown  Tyrannosaurus rex ," says Zanno. All of the results point to one conclusion, according to Zanno and Napoli. This was no teen  T. rex . This was a fully grown  Nanotyrannus lancensis  — the same species first identified in the 1940s and later largely dismissed by the paleontological community. It was "a small, slender pursuit predator that could run under the legs of a  T. rex ," explains Zanno. In addition, while making models of all those other alleged  T. rex  skeletons, Zanno says they identified another new species of tyrannosaur, one they're calling  Nanotyrannus lethaeus . "The name comes from Greco-Roman mythology for the [Lethe] River where souls used to drink and forget their prior lives and be reincarnated," she says. "That's a reference to this animal having been under our nose and not recognized for what it was." For years, most researchers believed there was just one tyrannosaur —  rex . But now the king has been de-throned. There were at least two other tyrannosaurs holding court. "It tells us that these end-Cretaceous ecosystems right before the asteroid hit were flourishing," says Zanno. "They had an abundance of different predators. And refutes this idea that dinosaurs were in decline before the asteroid struck." Loving being wrong Thomas Holtz , a paleontologist at the University of Maryland who wasn't involved in the research, welcomes the broader picture of tyrannosaur diversity proposed by the new study. "I always said with sufficient evidence, I'd be happy to embrace it," he says. "And now I can because there's sufficient evidence. I think they've made a very strong case." Though, he adds, "We'll see if it lasts. As I like to point out, taxonomy is not permanent," referring to the study of how organisms are classified (and, sometimes, re-classified). Holtz argues that one consequence of the study is that paleontologists no longer know what a juvenile  T. rex  looked like — because previously assumed "teenagers" were likely  Nanotyrannus . That's an arena of future research and discovery, along with fleshing out the varied biologies and behaviors of this growing group of tyrannosaurs. Zanno agrees that there remains much to understand. She believes there's likely to be additional dinosaur species that have been hidden in plain sight in museums and collections across the world. "This is why I love science," says Zanno. "I have the only job in the world where my job is to second-guess myself every day and everything I think I know." "When it comes to shedding doubt on research on Earth's most famous dinosaur," she says, referring to  T. rex , "that's an intimidating endeavor. But this is how we grow as a profession and how we grow as scientists." Zanno believes this study will pave the way for paleontologists to look for more complex patterns in this and other prehistoric ecosystems. "From here forward," Zanno adds, "what I'm most thrilled about is how much we stand to learn by recognizing that we got it wrong the first time." 
         
         Transcript 
         JUANA SUMMERS, HOST:   Think of Tyrannosaurus rex, a fearsome dinosaur and the top predator stalking the late Cretaceous. Well, a new discovery suggests T. rex likely shared its dominion with another tyrannosaur species. The king had company. Here's science reporter Ari Daniel. DANIEL: ...Whose friend had found an exposed pelvis and femur at the bottom of a canyon in eastern Montana. The bones belong to a stunning triceratops. Then after excavating for about two weeks, there in the dug-up sand, Phipps spotted something the color of chocolate - a claw. But triceratops didn't have claws. PHIPPS: I'm like, what? I start brushing, and all of a sudden this arm starts to appear and part of the leg. Oh, man, my hat went in the air about 200 feet (laughter) 'cause I was like, no way. There's another dinosaur in here. DANIEL: This was a bipedal, carnivorous tyrannosaur entwined with the triceratops. PHIPPS: Just laying like they died. DANIEL: Phipps sold the fossils to the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, where Lindsay Zanno is head of paleontology. LINDSAY ZANNO: It's one of the most incredible specimens from the late Cretaceous in North America I've ever seen. DANIEL: Zanno and the museum built an entire wing around the dueling dinosaurs to house a live-action research experience. ZANNO: It's the only place in the world where you get to enter the working paleo lab and talk to the scientific team. DANIEL: Like many of her colleagues, Zanno started out thinking the carnivorous dinosaur was a juvenile T. rex, perhaps the most complete teenage tyrannosaur ever found. ZANNO: But as soon as we started actually studying this specimen, we realized there were a lot of red flags. DANIEL: One red flag was the arm bones, which were unlike T. rex's puny appendages. ZANNO: These are powerful arms with large claws, large hands. DANIEL: The animal had fewer tail vertebrae than T. rex and more teeth. ZANNO: But maybe the most damning thing that we did was we were able to figure out that our animal is not a juvenile at all. DANIEL: By slicing through the limb bones to examine the growth rings, Zanno and her colleagues found this animal was done growing when it died. It all pointed to one conclusion, she says. This was no teen T. rex. This was a different tyrannosaur species whose existence was long dismissed by most paleontologists. This was a fully grown Nanotyrannus lancensis. ZANNO: A small, slender pursuit predator that could run under the legs of a T. rex. This is an animal that's using its arms to hunt prey. Tyrannosaurus rex is an animal that's a mouth on legs. DANIEL: For years, most researchers believe there was just one tyrannosaur, rex. This work dethrones the king. There were other tyrannosaurs holding court. ZANNO: It tells us that these end Cretaceous ecosystems were flourishing before the asteroid struck. DANIEL: The findings appear in the journal Nature. Thomas Holtz is a paleontologist at the University of Maryland who wasn't involved in the study. He welcomes the broader picture of tyrannosaur diversity. articles.title: King Charles III Strips Prince Andrew of Titles and Evicts Him from Royal Lodge
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: King Charles III has made a rare and historic decision to strip Prince Andrew of his royal titles and evict him from Royal Lodge, following sustained public and media pressure over his longstanding, undisclosed connection with sex offender Jeffrey Epstein and allegations of sexual abuse from Virginia Roberts Giuffre. The move marks the first time a British prince has lost his title since 1919 and underscores a dramatic shift in how royal families are expected to address serious misconduct. The action comes after Giuffre's posthumous memoir 'Nobody’s Girl' revealed multiple alleged sexual encounters with Andrew when she was 17, and new emails showed he maintained contact with Epstein longer than previously admitted. Though Andrew has previously denied the claims and paid a $1 million out-of-court settlement, the royal family has formally condemned the behavior, stating that the actions were 'necessary' and expressing sympathy for survivors of abuse. Prince Andrew, who was once celebrated as a royal favorite and hero of the Falklands War, now faces a complete loss of status, being renamed Andrew Mountbatten Windsor and relocated to a property on the Sandringham estate. The decision has sparked global attention and debate about accountability, transparency, and the role of power in protecting victims.
keyTakeAways: King Charles III stripped Prince Andrew of his royal titles and evicted him from Royal Lodge after weeks of public pressure related to his connections with Jeffrey Epstein and sexual abuse allegations.
Prince Andrew was previously known as the Duke of York and held multiple noble titles including Earl of Inverness and Baron Killyleagh, which are now formally revoked.

The decision follows revelations from Virginia Roberts Giuffre’s posthumous memoir 'Nobody’s Girl,' which detailed alleged sexual encounters with Andrew when she was 17, and new emails showing Andrew maintained contact with Epstein longer than admitted.
Prince Andrew had previously denied the allegations and paid a million-dollar out-of-court settlement in 2022, acknowledging Giuffre’s suffering without admitting guilt.
The move by the king is unprecedented in modern British royal history, as it marks the first time a prince has been stripped of the title 'prince' since 1919.
Public outrage intensified after a 2024 incident where the king was heckled at an event, prompting scrutiny over his awareness of Andrew’s ties to Epstein.
Andrew will now be known as Andrew Mountbatten Windsor and must vacate Royal Lodge; he will be relocated to a property on the Sandringham estate and receive private financial support from the king.
Giuffre’s brother, Skye Roberts, celebrated the downfall of Andrew, calling it a victory for his sister’s courage and truth, who died by suicide in April 2024.
The decision reflects a broader global shift in how powerful institutions handle accountability for sexual abuse and historical misconduct.

articles.title: Senators Demand Transparency Over ICE's Use of WRAP Restraints on Deportation Flights
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A group of 11 Democratic U.S. senators, including Chris Van Hollen, Elizabeth Warren, Cory Booker, Alex Padilla, and Tammy Duckworth, have raised serious human rights concerns over the secretive and prolonged use of full-body restraints known as the WRAP by U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) on deportation flights dating back to 2020. The senators demand full transparency and accountability, criticizing the agency for withholding information and using the restraints in ways that resemble punishment or torture. The AP investigation revealed that ICE has not provided public records of WRAP usage, and federal lawsuits and fatal cases involving the device have intensified scrutiny. The manufacturer, Safe Restraints Inc., claims the device is designed to prevent injury, but its widespread use and lack of oversight — especially under the Trump administrations — have led to accusations of abuse. U.S. Representative Delia Ramirez is actively drafting legislation to restrict ICE’s use of the device, highlighting concerns about safety, dignity, and due process. The U.S. Department of Homeland Security has not responded to detailed inquiries, and the situation underscores a broader pattern of opacity in immigration enforcement operations.
keyTakeAways: The U.S. government, particularly ICE and DHS, has been criticized for maintaining 'near-total secrecy' around the use of full-body restraints (WRAP) on immigration detainees during deportation flights.

A letter from 11 Democratic U.S. senators, including Chris Van Hollen, Elizabeth Warren, Cory Booker, Alex Padilla, and Tammy Duckworth, demands transparency and accountability from ICE over its use of the WRAP device.
The WRAP, a black and yellow full-body restraint, has been linked to federal lawsuits alleging it is used as punishment or torture, and advocates say it is not being tracked as required by law.
ICE has not provided public records documenting the use of the WRAP, despite repeated requests, and DHS has not responded to detailed questions from the AP about its use.

The manufacturer, Safe Restraints Inc., states the device is designed to prevent injury and opposes misuse, but federal purchasing records show that about 91% of WRAP purchases since 2015 occurred under the Trump administrations.
The AP reported at least 12 fatalities in the past decade where the WRAP was used by local law enforcement or jailers, and autopsies indicated restraint played a role in death.
U.S. Representative Delia Ramirez is working on a legislative bill to restrict ICE’s use of the WRAP, citing concerns about safety, dignity, and human rights.
Senators argue that the lack of transparency from DHS and ICE indicates a systemic failure in accountability, suggesting that the agency may be acting beyond oversight.

articles.title: Justice Department Investigating Alleged Fraud by Black Lives Matter Leaders Over Donor Funds
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: The U.S. Justice Department is investigating whether leaders of the Black Lives Matter Global Network Foundation defrauded donors who contributed tens of millions of dollars during 2020 protests following the murder of George Floyd. The investigation, which began during the Biden administration and has seen renewed attention under the Trump administration, includes subpoenas and a search warrant. Critics have long accused the foundation of financial opacity, notably after it was revealed in 2022 that donations were used to purchase a $6 million property in Los Angeles. While the foundation maintains that it is not under criminal investigation and emphasizes transparency and accountability, the probe raises broader concerns about political targeting of progressive groups and the accountability of movements receiving large public donations. The investigation is being led by Bill Essayli, a former Republican assemblyman with a history of opposing BLM and immigrant protections, which has raised questions about impartiality. The foundation’s recent Form 990 filing shows $28 million in assets as of June 2024, and prior state-level scrutiny, such as Indiana Attorney General Todd Rokita’s lawsuit, has already been resolved without action.
keyTakeAways: The Justice Department is investigating whether leaders of the Black Lives Matter Global Network Foundation defrauded donors who contributed tens of millions of dollars in 2020.
The investigation includes subpoenas and a search warrant issued to the BLM Global Network Foundation and affiliated Black-led organizations.
Critics have long accused BLM leaders of poor financial transparency, notably after the 2022 revelation of a $6 million property purchase in Los Angeles.
The foundation maintains that it is not under criminal investigation and emphasizes transparency and accountability.

The investigation is being conducted by the U.S. Attorney’s Office for the Central District of California, led by Bill Essayli, a former Republican assemblyman with a history of opposing immigrant protections and criticizing BLM.

No prior investigations have yielded proof of impropriety, and the foundation has previously released detailed tax documents to demonstrate financial stewardship.

articles.title: Dutch Election Ends in Historic Tie Between PVV and D66, Sparking Coalition Crisis
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: In the Netherlands, the 2025 general election resulted in a historic tie between the far-right Party for Freedom (PVV), led by Geert Wilders, and the centrist D66, led by Rob Jetten, with both securing 26 seats in the 150-seat House of Representatives. This marks the first time in Dutch history that two parties have held the lead in a general election, leading to a significant political deadlock and delay in forming a coalition. Mainstream parties have ruled out cooperation with PVV due to Wilders’ past actions, particularly his decision to break up a migration-focused coalition in June 2025. A potential centrist coalition is being considered, including D66, the Labor Party, Green Left, Christian Democrats, and the People’s Party for Freedom and Democracy. The outcome reflects deep societal polarization, with rising anti-immigration sentiment, violence at rallies, and a surge in support for right-wing parties such as JA21. The vote count process was delayed by a fire in Venray and incomplete mail-in ballots, and the final certification will be conducted by the Electoral College. Experts like Henk van der Kolk and Armida van Rij warn that this election signals a growing influence of populism and a shift away from the Netherlands' historical reputation for tolerance.
keyTakeAways: The Dutch general election ended in a historic tie between the far-right Party for Freedom (PVV) and the centrist D66, with both parties winning 26 seats in a 150-seat House of Representatives.
This is the first time in Dutch history that two parties have tied for the largest number of seats, creating a major political deadlock and delaying coalition formation.
Mainstream parties, including D66, have ruled out forming coalitions with the PVV due to Geert Wilders' past actions, such as torpedoing a migration-focused coalition in June 2025.
The election reflects deep societal polarization in the Netherlands, with rising anti-immigration sentiment, violence at rallies, and new gains by right-wing parties like JA21.
A potential coalition path is emerging involving D66, the Labor Party, Green Left, Christian Democrats, and People’s Party for Freedom and Democracy, bypassing a direct PVV alliance.
Former European Commission vice president Frans Timmermans announced his exit from Dutch politics following the center-left bloc’s electoral losses.
The vote count process faced delays due to technical issues, including a fire in Venray, and incomplete mail-in ballots from 135,000 voters.
The outcome underscores the growing influence of populist and anti-immigration political forces in the Netherlands, challenging its historical reputation for tolerance.

articles.title: New Evidence Identifies Mystery Dinosaur as Distinct Species, Not Juvenile T. rex
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: A new complete skeleton discovered in Montana's Hell Creek Formation has provided decisive evidence that a long-debated dinosaur, previously thought to be a juvenile Tyrannosaurus rex, is actually a distinct species — Nanotyrannus lancensis. Growth rings and anatomical differences in skull structure, nerve patterns, and sinuses indicate the animal was an adult, not a young T. rex. This finding rewrites decades of paleontological research and suggests that multiple predator species, including a smaller relative of T. rex, roamed during the end of the dinosaur era. The fossil, nicknamed 'Dueling Dinosaurs' because it was found with a Triceratops, is now on display at the North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences. While the study by Lindsay Zanno and James Napoli offers strong support for the species' existence, experts like Holly Woodward and Thomas Carr remain cautious, noting that some earlier fossils like 'Jane' are not yet confirmed as new species, and the debate over predator dynamics continues.
keyTakeAways: A new complete skeleton discovered in Montana’s Hell Creek Formation reveals a previously unidentified dinosaur species, not a juvenile T. rex.
Growth rings in the bones indicate the animal was an adult, approximately half the size of a full-sized T. rex.
Structural and neurological differences between the skull and an adult T. rex suggest it is not a juvenile, but a distinct species.
The species is proposed to be Nanotyrannus lancensis, a distant relative of T. rex, though some scientists remain unconvinced.
The fossil was found intertwined with a Triceratops skeleton and is nicknamed 'Dueling Dinosaurs'.
The discovery challenges decades of prior research and suggests the presence of multiple predator species at the end of the dinosaur era.
The study, co-authored by Lindsay Zanno and James Napoli, is published in Nature and provides stronger evidence than ever for the existence of Nanotyrannus.

articles.title: Senate Passes Resolution to Reverse Trump’s Tariff Policies Amid Trade Negotiations with China
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: On October 30, 2025, the U.S. Senate passed a resolution to nullify many of President Donald Trump’s global tariffs, with a 51-47 vote including four Republican senators. The move, which relies on a decades-old congressional law to challenge presidential national emergencies, reflects bipartisan concern over the economic harm caused by rising prices and trade disruptions. While Trump celebrated his negotiations with Chinese leader Xi Jinping as a success—announcing China would buy 25 million metric tons of U.S. soybeans annually for three years—Democrats and some Republicans argue the tariffs have worsened inflation and harmed rural and agricultural communities. Despite the resolution’s passage, it is unlikely to pass in the House or survive a Trump veto, highlighting the political fragility of such legislative challenges. The vote underscores deep divisions within the Republican Party over trade policy, with some senators, like Rand Paul and Mitch McConnell, supporting legislative action to check executive overreach.
keyTakeAways: The Senate passed a resolution on October 30, 2025, to nullify many of President Donald Trump’s global tariffs, reflecting bipartisan opposition to his trade policies.

The resolution, passed 51-47, included four Republican senators (including Rand Paul, Mitch McConnell, Lisa Murkowski, and Susan Collins) voting with Democrats, exposing internal divisions within the Republican Party.
The resolution relies on a decades-old congressional law allowing the nullification of presidential national emergencies used to justify tariffs.
Despite the passage, the legislation is unlikely to take effect due to a House Republican rule blocking such resolutions and a likely Trump veto.
Trump claimed success in trade negotiations with China, announcing China would buy 25 million metric tons of U.S. soybeans annually for three years, citing 'prosperity and security' for Americans.
However, experts and senators like Ron Wyden and Chuck Schumer argue that tariffs have increased prices, harmed farmers, and caused economic strain, especially in rural and agricultural regions.
Republican senators like Roger Marshall and Mike Crapo expressed mixed views—supporting the deal with China due to soybean exports but acknowledging the ongoing economic challenges for farmers.
China had previously purchased nearly 27 million metric tons of U.S. soybeans in 2024, so the new agreement returns sales to a lower level, indicating a partial recovery rather than full restoration.

articles.title: Tropical Storm Melissa takes aim at Caribbean, islands on alert
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Tropical Storm Melissa, the 13th named storm of the 2025 Atlantic hurricane season and the first to form in the Caribbean this year, is moving slowly westward and threatening the Caribbean region with heavy rainfall and dangerous flooding. Jamaica, Haiti, the Dominican Republic, Aruba, and Puerto Rico are at risk, with Jamaica’s eastern region potentially receiving up to 12 inches of rain. The storm is expected to strengthen into a hurricane by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend. Officials are urging residents in flood-prone areas to evacuate. The U.S. National Hurricane Center and NOAA provide critical data and seasonal context, highlighting both immediate dangers and long-term storm patterns.

Jamaica’s eastern region could receive up to 12 inches (300mm) of rain, which is considered significant and a primary concern.
Similar heavy rainfall is forecast for southern Haiti and the southern Dominican Republic, with potential for even more rain depending on the storm’s path.
Western Jamaica, southern Hispaniola, Aruba, and Puerto Rico are also facing heavy rain forecasts.
Melissa has maximum sustained winds of 50mph (85km/h) and is moving west at 2mph (4km/h), centered about 335 miles south-southwest of Port-au-Prince and 295 miles south-southeast of Kingston.
The US National Hurricane Center predicts Melissa could strengthen into a hurricane by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend.
Melissa is the 13th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season and the first named storm to form in the Caribbean this year.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicts an above-normal Atlantic hurricane season with 13 to 18 named storms, five to nine hurricanes, and two to five major hurricanes (winds of 111mph or greater).

articles.content:
Published: 2025-10-23T06:29:43+00:00

Title: Tropical Storm Melissa takes aim at Caribbean, islands on alert

Tropical Storm Melissa is threatening the Caribbean Sea islands with dangerous landslides and life-threatening flooding, as officials urge residents of flood-prone areas to seek higher ground and shelter.

Jamaica’s eastern region could see up to 12 inches (300mm) of rain. “Now that is significant rainfall, and that is the main thing that we should be mindful of at this time,” Evan Thompson, director of Jamaica’s Meteorological Service, said.

Similar rainfall amounts were expected for southern Haiti and the southern Dominican Republic through Saturday, with even more rain possible locally, depending on Melissa’s path later in the week.

Heavy rain was also forecast for western Jamaica, southern Hispaniola, Aruba and Puerto Rico.

Melissa had maximum sustained winds of 50mph (85km/h) and was moving west at 2mph (4km/h) late on Wednesday night, according to the US National Hurricane Center in Miami.

The slow-moving storm was centred about 335 miles (535km) south-southwest of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and some 295 miles (475km) south-southeast of Kingston, Jamaica.

The NHC said the storm could strengthen gradually in the coming days and grow into a  hurricane  by Friday and a major hurricane by the late weekend.

Heavy rains in the Dominican Republic have already disrupted traffic and led to the cancellation of sports events.

Melissa is the 13th named storm of the Atlantic hurricane season, and the first named storm to form in the Caribbean this year.

The National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration predicted an above-normal Atlantic hurricane season – which runs from June 1 to November 30 – with 13 to 18 named storms.

Of those, five to nine were forecast to become hurricanes, including two to five major hurricanes, which pack winds of 111mph or greater.

articles.title: Republicans Push Supreme Court to Allow Lawsuit Against Cisco Over Alleged Role in China's Falun Gong Persecution
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Two prominent Republican lawmakers, Chris Smith and John Moolenaar, are urging the U.S. Supreme Court to allow a lawsuit against tech giant Cisco to proceed, alleging that the company provided technology used to persecute members of the Falun Gong spiritual movement in China. The case, which dates back to 2008 and 2011, centers on whether U.S. law permits American corporations to be held liable for human rights abuses committed abroad through their technology exports. A 2023 federal appeals court ruled against Cisco’s claims under the Alien Tort Statute and Torture Victim Protection Act, allowing the case to continue. The Supreme Court is now considering whether to hear the case, with the Trump administration’s solicitor general expected to file a brief. The case has broader implications for U.S. corporate responsibility, foreign policy, and the balance between national security and human rights, especially as technology exports to authoritarian regimes become a growing point of contention.
keyTakeAways: The U.S. Supreme Court is being asked to rule on whether American tech companies can be held liable under U.S. law for aiding human rights abuses committed by foreign governments, specifically in China.

Cisco is challenging a 2023 federal appeals court decision that allowed a lawsuit by Falun Gong members to proceed, arguing that U.S. law does not permit such suits over foreign human rights violations.

The lawsuit alleges that Cisco tailored its surveillance technology to identify and track Falun Gong members, with internal documents from 2008 showing explicit marketing of such tools as 'threats' in China.
The case raises broader concerns about U.S. companies exporting technology to authoritarian regimes and the potential precedent it would set for corporate liability in foreign human rights cases.

The Trump administration and Republican lawmakers are urging the Supreme Court to allow the case to proceed, citing a pattern of U.S. governments across administrations enabling tech exports to China despite warnings about human rights abuses.
The case is seen as a pivotal moment in U.S.-China tech relations, where corporate responsibility and national security intersect with international human rights standards.

articles.content:
Published: 2025-10-29T23:36:41+00:00

Title: RFK Jr walks back Trump administration’s claims linking Tylenol and autism

United States Health and Human Services Secretary Robert F Kennedy Jr has partially walked back his  warning  that taking Tylenol during pregnancy is directly linked to autism in children.

In a news conference on Wednesday, Kennedy struck a more moderate tone than he generally has in his past public appearances.

“The causative association between Tylenol given in pregnancy and the perinatal periods is not sufficient to say it definitely causes autism,” Kennedy told reporters. “But it’s very suggestive.”

“There should be a cautious approach to it,” he added. “ That’s why our message to patients, to mothers, to people who are pregnant and to the mothers of young children is: Consult your physician.”

Wednesday’s statement is closer in line with the guidance of  reputable health agencies .

While some studies have raised the possibility of a link between Tylenol and autism, there have been no conclusive findings. Pregnant women are advised to consult a doctor before taking the medication.

The World Health Organization reiterated the point in September, noting that “no consistent association has been established” between the medication and autism, despite “extensive research”.

But claims to the contrary have already prompted efforts to limit the availability of Tylenol, a popular brand of acetaminophen, a fever- and pain-reducing medication.

On Tuesday, Texas Attorney General Ken Paxton launched a lawsuit accusing Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue, the companies behind the over-the-counter pain reliever, of deceptive practices.

In doing so, he reiterated misinformation shared by President Donald Trump and government officials like Kennedy.

“By holding Big Pharma accountable for poisoning our people, we will help Make America Healthy Again,” Paxton said in a statement, giving a nod to Kennedy’s MAHA slogan.

The suit alleges that Johnson & Johnson and Kenvue violated Texas consumer protection laws by having “deceptively marketed Tylenol as the only safe painkiller for pregnant women”.

It was the latest instance of scientific misinformation being perpetuated by top officials. Both Trump and Kennedy have repeatedly spread scientific misinformation throughout their political careers.

Trump linked autism and the painkiller during a news conference in September, without providing reputable scientific findings to back the claim.

“[Using] acetaminophen – is that OK? – which is basically, commonly known as Tylenol, during pregnancy can be associated with a very increased risk of autism,” Trump said on September 22. “So taking Tylenol is not good. I’ll say it. It’s not good.”

Kennedy has offered his own sweeping statements about Tylenol and its alleged risks, despite having no professional medical background.

“Anyone who takes this stuff during pregnancy, unless they have to, is irresponsible,” he said in a cabinet meeting on October 9.

Kennedy also mischaracterised studies on male circumcision earlier this month. He  falsely  said the studies showed an increase in autism among children who were “circumcised early”.

“It’s highly likely because they’re given Tylenol,” he added.

Kenvue stressed in a statement on Tuesday that acetaminophen is the safest pain reliever option for pregnant women, noting that high fevers and pain are potential risks to pregnancies if left untreated.

“We stand firmly with the global medical community that acknowledges the safety of acetaminophen and believe we will continue to be successful in litigation as these claims lack legal merit and scientific support,” Kenvue said.

articles.title: Why has Pakistan’s HPV vaccine campaign faced a backlash?
articles.summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan launched a national HPV vaccine campaign in September 2025 to vaccinate over 13 million girls aged 9 to 14, aiming to combat cervical cancer — which kills eight women daily in the country. The campaign, supported by the WHO and GAVI, used the single-dose Cecolin vaccine, which contains non-infectious proteins and is considered safe. Despite significant public resistance fueled by conspiracy theories — including claims of infertility, ties to foreign espionage, and misinformation about sexual transmission — the campaign was extended by four days to address hesitancy. A key turning point was when federal health minister Syed Mustafa Kamal publicly vaccinated his daughter, which helped improve public trust. While the campaign reached only 78% of its target, it represents a vital step toward achieving the WHO’s global goal of eradicating cervical cancer by 2030. Past incidents, such as the CIA’s fake hepatitis B campaign in Abbottabad, have deepened societal mistrust, and misinformation, including a viral false video of girls collapsing, further complicated outreach. Experts emphasize that the vaccine offers long-term protection and is critical for preventing cervical cancer, especially in a context where sexual abuse remains prevalent.
keyTakeAways: Pakistan launched its first national HPV vaccine campaign in September 2025, aiming to vaccinate over 13 million girls aged 9 to 14.
The campaign faced strong public resistance due to conspiracy theories and misinformation, including claims that the vaccine causes infertility or is linked to foreign espionage.
The vaccine used is Cecolin, a single-dose HPV vaccine developed in China and containing recombinant L1 capsid proteins, not live virus, and has been approved by the WHO as safe and effective.
Despite initial low uptake — only 78% of the target was reached — the campaign was extended by four days to address hesitancy and improve reach.
The campaign was supported by the WHO, the government of Pakistan, and GAVI, with 49,000 female health workers trained to administer the vaccine.
The vaccine is currently free of cost for girls aged 9–14, with plans to expand to boys and men in the future.
Societal mistrust of vaccines in Pakistan is rooted in past incidents, such as the CIA’s fake hepatitis B campaign in Abbottabad in 2011, which fueled deep-seated skepticism.
A viral video falsely showing girls collapsing after vaccination was debunked — the collapse was due to police clashes, not the vaccine.
Experts emphasize that HPV causes cervical cancer in over 95% of global cases, and early prevention through vaccination can prevent cancer development decades later.
The campaign is seen as a critical step toward reducing cervical cancer rates in Pakistan, where over 5,000 new cases occur annually and eight women die from the disease every day.
